tit.cmt: 布団の説明がないため加えました。

sen.j: 『蒲団』（ふとん）は、田山花袋の中編小説。
sen.e: "Futon" is a short novel which was written by Katai TAYAMA.
"Futon" is a short novel which was written by Katai TAYAMA.
"Futon" is a short novel which was written by Katai TAYAMA.

sen.j: 「新小説」1907年8月号に掲載され、のち易風社から刊行された『花袋集』に収録された。
sen.e: It was published in a magazine, 'Shinshosetsu,' for August 1907, and later it was collected in "Kataishu" (collection of Katai), which was published through Ekifusha.
It was published in the August 1907 issue of 'Shinshosetsu' magazine, and later it was included in "Kataishu" (collection of Katai), which was published through Ekifusha.
sen.cmt: 訳文で掲載号が「for August 1907」となっていますが、この場合前置詞用法が間違っています。この点修正しました。「収録」が「was collected」となっていますが、あまり使わない言い方ですので、一般的な「included」に変更しました。
sen.e: It was published in the August 1907 issue of 'Shinshosetsu' magazine, and later it was included in "Kataishu" (collection of Katai), which was published through Ekifusha.

sen.j: 花袋に師事していた弟子の岡田美知代とのかかわりをもとに描いた小説。
sen.e: It is a novel based on the relationship with Michiyo OKADA, who was a disciple of Katai.
It is a novel based on the relationship with Michiyo OKADA, who was a disciple of Katai.
It is a novel based on the relationship with Michiyo OKADA, who was a disciple of Katai.

sen.j: 日本における自然主義文学、また私小説の出発点に位置する作品である。
sen.e: This work has been regarded as a Japanese naturalist literature and also the pioneer of an "I" novel.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This work has been regarded as the pioneer of Japanese naturalist literature and "I" novel genre found in Japanese literally works, which is often based on the author's own life.
sen.cmt: 1. 訳文は原文の意味をただしく読解していません。原文では、「この作品は自然主義文学、私小説双方の出発点に位置する」という意味ですが、訳文は「この小説は自然主義文学にカテゴライズされ、（その上で）私小説の出発点に位置している」という役になっています。この点留意し訂正しました。2. 私小説を「I novel」としているのは辞書などで記載されているとおりなのですが、通常、I novelとした場合にも大抵はその説明が続きます。これは私小説を日本の小説の一ジャンルと見ているためで、日本文学の知識がある人以外に一般的に知られている言葉ではありません。当然この「I novel」という英訳がスタンダードなわけではなく、ドイツなどでは当然ドイツ語で「Ich Roman」となります。説明を付け加えるべきと考え加筆しました。
sen.e: This work has been regarded as the pioneer of Japanese naturalist literature and "I" novel genre found in Japanese literally works, which is often based on the author's own life.

sen.j: 末尾において主人公が女弟子の使っていた蒲団の匂いをかぐ場面など、性を露悪的にまで描き出した内容が当時の文壇とジャーナリズムに大きな反響を巻き起こした。
sen.e: It described sex badly, for example, the main character smelled futon which his female disciple used, so it evoked a massive response in the literary circles and journalism in those days.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This novel stirred up a sensation in the literary circles and journalism in those days, because the content intentionally exagerated the desire and sexuality in its description; for example, there is a scene at the end of this novel that the main male character smelled the linging scent of his female disciple left on her futon.
sen.cmt: 「性を露悪的に描き出した」という原文を「described sex badly」と訳すと直訳的で一般に見る文章ではありません。この点留意し訂正しました。原文を読んでいないのでわかりませんが、本項後程にあるあらすじに示された内容からは性の露悪的表現と言えるほどのものとは思えません。あくまで文学作品における表現ですので、その点を汲み取り訳しています。
sen.e: This novel stirred up a sensation in the literary circles and journalism in those days, because the content intentionally exagerated the desire and sexuality in its description; for example, there is a scene at the end of this novel that the main male character smelled the linging scent of his female disciple left on her futon.

sen.j: 自分のことを暴露する小説としては、これより先に森鴎外の「舞姫」があったが、下層のドイツ人女性との恋愛の末妊娠させて捨てるという内容であり、女弟子に片想いをし、性欲の悶えを描くという花袋の手法ほどの衝撃は与えなかった。
sen.e: Maihime' (The Dancing Girl) by Ogai MORI was also a novel in which the author revealed himself, but it was a story of a Japanese man who fell in love with the German girl in the lower class, made her pregnant, and then deserted her, so it did not gave people a shock as much as Katai's work which dealt with an agony of sex.

There was also a a novel by Ogai MORI, 'Maihime,' (The Dancing Girl) in which the author revealed himself by telling a story of a Japanese man, who fell in love with the German girl in lower class, made her pregnant, and then deserted her; however, Ogai's novel was not as shocking as Katai's work which dealt with the agony of sexual desire caused by the unrequited love toward a female disciple.
sen.cmt: 「〜, so 〜」という接続は英文では非常に口語調で英文では避けられる用法です。この部分で意味の違う文に分かれているので、前後の関係をはっきりさせるために、「；」を用いて前後を区切り、前後の意味転換を示す「however」をここで用いました。2. なお、原文にありながら訳されていない部分がありました。「女弟子に片思いをし」という部分が欠如していましたので追加しました。訳文、「it did not gave people-」となっており基本的な文法ミスがあります。またこの言い回しは直訳的ですので、一般的なものに修正しました。
sen.e: There was also a a novel by Ogai MORI, 'Maihime,' (The Dancing Girl) in which the author revealed himself by telling a story of a Japanese man, who fell in love with the German girl in lower class, made her pregnant, and then deserted her; however, Ogai's novel was not as shocking as Katai's work which dealt with the agony of sexual desire caused by the unrequited love toward a female disciple.

sen.j: 小栗風葉は「中年の恋」という主題にのみ着目して、「蒲団」に続いて「恋ざめ」を書いたが、自然主義陣営の仲間入りはできなかった。
sen.e: Fuyo OGURI focused only on the subject of 'a love of middle age,' and wrote 'Koizame' after 'Futon' was published, but he could not join the naturalist community.

Fuyo OGURI wrote 'Koizame' in his attempt to follow after Katai's 'Futon' by focusing on the 'love of a middle-aged person', yet this theme was partial compared to the dense themes of 'Futon' and OGURI could not participate in the community of naturalism movement.
sen.cmt: 原文の読解から英訳すべきところを原文の直訳にとどまっているため、英訳を読んだだけでは意味があまりわかりません。多少の意訳が必要と思われたため追加修正しました。なお、自然主義者を「naturalist」とすると、「博物学者、動物学者等」別の意味が加わってきます。「naturalism movement」と特定したほうが良いと考え修正しました。
sen.e: Fuyo OGURI wrote 'Koizame' in his attempt to follow after Katai's 'Futon' by focusing on the 'love of a middle-aged person', yet this theme was partial compared to the dense themes of 'Futon' and OGURI could not participate in the community of naturalism movement.

sen.j: 以後3年ほど、花袋は文壇に君臨したが、一般読者にはあまり受けなかった。
sen.e: Since then Katai had been dominant in the field of literature for about three years, but the general readers did not accept him very much.
Since the release of this novel, Katai had been dominant in the literally circle for about three years, but his works were not welcomed very much by general readers.
sen.cmt: 「文壇」は「field of literature」よりもさらに限定された「literally circle」としたほうが良いと思います。「since then」との英訳では、何に対してそれからなのかが一瞬わかりづらいため、再記述しました。「一般読者にはあまり受けなかった」の訳を「the general readers did not accept "him" very much」とすると、「彼を受け入れなかった」の意味になります。間違いではありませんが、一応「彼の作品は受けなかった」の原文に近いよう修正しました。定冠詞「the」も消去しています。
sen.e: Since the release of this novel, Katai had been dominant in the literally circle for about three years, but his works were not welcomed very much by general readers.

sen.j: 花袋の盟友ともいうべき島崎藤村は、その後、姪との情事を描いた『新生』を書いて花袋にも衝撃を与えた。
sen.e: Toson SHIMAZAKI, a sworn friend of Katai, later wrote "Shinsei," a novel dealing with a love affair with his niece, and it gave Katai a shock, too.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A sworn friend of Katai, Toson SHIMAZAKI later wrote "Shinsei," which shocked even Katai by the contents of the novel confessing the love affair of Toson with his own niece.
sen.cmt: 「花袋にも衝撃を与えた」という部分が訳文では付随的な文になっており、衝撃の理由が訳文でははっきりしません。この部分が主題と思えましたのでこの点に留意し、加筆しました。他の項目では固有名（小説名）について「'...'」（single quotation mark）で統一していますが、ここではdouble quotationが用いられていたため統一のため修正しました。
sen.e: A sworn friend of Katai, Toson SHIMAZAKI later wrote "Shinsei," which shocked even Katai by the contents of the novel confessing the love affair of Toson with his own niece.

sen.j: しかし、私小説の本格的な始まりは、大正2年の近松秋江「疑惑」と木村荘太「牽引」だとする説もあり、花袋や藤村はその後、むしろ平凡な日々を淡々と描く方向に向かった。
sen.e: However, there is an opinion that the real beginning of "I" novel was 'Suspicion' by Shuko CHIKAMATSU and 'Traction' by Sota KIMURA in 1913, and later Katai and Toson rather aimed at describing ordinary daily life in even tones.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, there is an opinion that the full-scale development of "I novel" began with 'Suspicion' by Shuko CHIKAMATSU and 'Traction' by Sota KIMURA both written in 1913; Katai and Toson gradually shifted from "I novel" and rather aimed at the direction of describing ordinary daily life scenes in a light and even tone.
sen.cmt: 「本格的な始まり」を「real beginning」としていますが、意味が多少異なるように思い修正しました。既に分割されている文章なのでさらに分割するのをためらわれたのだと思いますが、内容的には相反するものを併置した内容です。「;」で区切り、andによる相反する内容の接続を避けました。「淡々と」が多少説明不足に訳されていると思いましたので加筆しました。「even」の意味に合うよう、複数形だった「tones」を単数形としました。
sen.e: However, there is an opinion that the full-scale development of "I novel" began with 'Suspicion' by Shuko CHIKAMATSU and 'Traction' by Sota KIMURA both written in 1913; Katai and Toson gradually shifted from "I novel" and rather aimed at the direction of describing ordinary daily life scenes in a light and even tone.

tit.cmt: 対訳例に合わせ修正しました。

sen.j: 34歳くらいで、妻と三人の子供のある作家の竹中時雄のもとに、横山芳子という女学生が弟子入りを志願してくる。
sen.e: Yoshiko YOKOYAMA, a girl student, wanted to be a disciple of Akio TAKENAKA, a writer who was about 34 and had a wife and three children.

One day, a novelist Tokio TAKENAKA, who was about 34 years old and living with his wife and three children, received a letter from a female student named Yoshiko YOKOYAMA asking for becoming his deciple.
sen.cmt: コンマによる分節が著しく読みづらいのみならず意味が取りづらいです。分節の必要が内容な文章に修正しました。「時雄」という人名が「Akio」になっていましたので訂正しました。また、続きの項の内容などから推察できるものを意訳により訳しています。
sen.e: One day, a novelist Tokio TAKENAKA, who was about 34 years old and living with his wife and three children, received a letter from a female student named Yoshiko YOKOYAMA asking for becoming his deciple.

sen.j: 始めは気の進まなかった時雄であったが、芳子と手紙をやりとりするうちにその将来性を見込み、師弟関係を結び芳子は上京してくる。
sen.e: Tokio, who did not feel like taking her as his disciple at first, came to expect her potentiality as he exchanging letters with Yoshiko, so she became his disciple and came to Tokyo.
Tokio, who did not feel like taking her as his disciple at first, came to expect her potentiality as he exchanged letters with Yoshiko, thus she became his disciple and moved to Tokyo.
sen.cmt: 「as he exchanging letters」など文法上のミスがあります。訂正しました。「so」による文章同士の接続を修正しました。
sen.e: Tokio, who did not feel like taking her as his disciple at first, came to expect her potentiality as he exchanged letters with Yoshiko, thus she became his disciple and moved to Tokyo.

sen.j: 時雄と芳子の関係ははたから見ると仲のよい男女であったが、芳子の恋人である田中秀夫も芳子を追って上京してくる。
sen.e: Apparently, Tokio and Yoshiko seem to be a man and a woman who were on good terms, but Hideo TANAKA, a lover of Yoshiko, also chased her to Tokyo.
From outside, Tokio and Yoshiko appeared to be a man and a woman on good terms; then Yoshiko's boyfriend Hideo TANAKA also came to Tokyo chasing after her.
sen.cmt: 「はたから見ると」を訳者は「Apparently」としていますが、これでは意味が異なります。修正しました。また、原文で前後の意味内容の異なる文をつなぐ際に否定形が用いられ、これを訳者は「but」を用いて訳していますが、内容を読むと「but」で接続するべき関係ではないことがわかります。その点留意し訂正しました。
sen.e: From outside, Tokio and Yoshiko appeared to be a man and a woman on good terms; then Yoshiko's boyfriend Hideo TANAKA also came to Tokyo chasing after her.

sen.j: 時雄は監視するために芳子を自らの家の2階に住まわせることにする。
sen.e: Tokio decided to have Yoshiko stay at the second floor of his house in order to keep watching on her.
Tokio decided to have Yoshiko stay at the second floor of his house, in order to keep an eye on her.
sen.cmt: 「in order to」の前にコンマを入れました。「監視する」を「keep watching on her」から「keep an eye on her」と修正しました。
sen.e: Tokio decided to have Yoshiko stay at the second floor of his house, in order to keep an eye on her.

sen.j: だが芳子と秀夫の仲は時雄の想像以上に進んでいて、怒った時雄は芳子を破門し父親と共に帰らせる。
sen.e: However, the relationship between Yoshiko and Hideo was more than Tokio had thought, so angry Tokio expelled her, making her go home with her father.
However, the relationship between Yoshiko and Hideo was more than Tokio had thought, thus in anger he expelled her and made her go home with her father.
sen.cmt: 再び「so」が用いられており、特にここでは強調のsoか接続のsoかもはっきりしません。この点留意し修正しました。「making her go home」における「making」の用法は不要だと思います。時制を「expelled」に合わせ併置して文意をわかりやすくしました。
sen.e: However, the relationship between Yoshiko and Hideo was more than Tokio had thought, thus in anger he expelled her and made her go home with her father.

sen.j: そして時雄は芳子のいない空虚感のために、芳子が寝ていた蒲団に顔をうずめ、泣くのであった。
sen.e: Then emptiness of losing Yoshiko made Tokio bury his head in Yoshiko's futon and cry.
Then emptiness of losing Yoshiko made Tokio bury his face into Yoshiko's futon and cry.
sen.cmt: 顔の訳を「head」から「face」に変更しました。
sen.e: Then emptiness of losing Yoshiko made Tokio bury his face into Yoshiko's futon and cry.
